index

GFM is a feature-rich library to ease the creation of video games / multimedia applications with the D programming language. Pick what you need.

Overview:

  • gfm.core:
    • : a dead simple queue/fifo/stack/ring-buffer, with a range interface. Synchronized queue for threads.
    • : aligned malloc/free/realloc.

  • gfm.math:
    • : small vectors for 2D and 3D.
    • : small matrices for 2D and 3D.
    • : quaternions.
    • : 16-bit floating point type.
    • : 2^N bits integers (recursive implementation, covers cent/ucent).
    • : half-open intervals (for eg. AABB).
    • : fixed-point numbers.
    • : rational numbers.
    • : random distributions: a port of SimpleRNG from John D. Cook.
    • : segment, triangle, sphere, ray, plane, frustum.
    • : useful math functions, polynomial solvers, statistics.

  • gfm.opengl:
    • OpenGL wrapper based on package derelict-gl3.
    • makes easier to use the OpenGL API correctly.
    • including a matrix stack to replace fixed pipeline.
    • including compilation of a single source for multiple shaders.
    • practical shader uniforms support: set them at any time, with id caching, and support pruned uniforms.
    • legacy multi-texture support which is needed for a low-spec game.
    • built-in OpenGL debug output forwarding.

  • gfm.net:
    • : URI parsing (RFC 3986).
    • : HTTP client (RFC 2616).

  • gfm.sdl2:
    • SDL 2.x wrapper based on package derelict-sdl2.
    • including SDL_image and SDL_ttf wrappers.
    • built-in SDL logging forwarding.

  • gfm.image:
    • : stb_image port, loads BMP, PNG, GIF and JPEG.

  • gfm.logger:
    • : coloured console logger implementation based on std.logger.

  • gfm.freeimage:
    • FreeImage wrapper based on package derelict-fi.

  • gfm.assimp:
    • Assimp wrapper based on package derelict-assimp3.

  • gfm.enet:
    • ENet wrapper based on package derelict-enet.

Dealing with resources in D.

Resource management in D needs more care than it seems at first ; more so than in C++ and as much as in C#.

The crux of the matter is that you cannot rely on a class destructor being called by the GC or even class destruction order.

A notable consequence is that when a class instance destructor is called, its members might have been destroyed already (unlike in C++).

You can verify this fact here: .

To simplify, the resource-ness of a class leaks on anything that owns it. This is an unavoidable fact of a GC with cycles and you have to deal with it, ie. you have to call close() methods manually before it's too late.

How to deal with it:

  • Call close() manually on resource classes.
  • A class with a close() method should have it called automatically by its destructor.
  • Use such friendly resource classes with , , , , or any other deterministic destruction mechanisms.
  • For maximum usefulness, a close() method should support being called several times.
